title: Re: Anyone bought/plans to buy Windows Vista?
content:
Well I like Linux primarily because if something goes wrong with the OS, given enough time, you can trace the problem back to a line in the kernel source and fix it yourself. I did this a while back when the driver for my network card would lock up the computer. It took me a couple of hours to find the problem, I added a "break;" statement in the right place, recompiled, and bingo - no more lockups.

If you get a problem like that with Windows, you're at the mercy of the hardware vendor to release an updated driver. I don't like losing control of my PC like that...it's like the worst-case trusted computing scenario, where you have to wait for some company to decide whether your computer should work or not [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

I saw a PC running Vista the other day and it certainly looks much spiffier - all the windows fade on and off the screen and there's generally a lot more eye candy, and of course it *really* slows down your PC, but from the user's point of view it's not really that much better.

Duh. Because Windows has been around for so long, a lot of people don't know that there are actually OS'es that work differently and thus do not have "EXEs". Since the core of an OS is different from that of another OS, they will both have to translate to their own version of machine code that gets passed onto the kernel/processor.

Sorry if that was unclear. No exes, but a special "executable" attribute to a file if it contains code that the OS can understand as a program.____________

title: Re: Anyone bought/plans to buy Windows Vista?

[quote]Quote:[hr]Since the core of an OS is different from that of another OS, they will both have to translate to their own version of machine code that gets passed onto the kernel/processor.[hr][/quote]Actually, all OSes that run on Intel, AMD and other x86 chips use the same x86 machine code - it's just the way data and executable headers are stored, and the functions called, that change. (This is why Wine works - it loads Windows executables and then provides them with all the functions they need to run)

title: Re: Anyone bought/plans to buy Windows Vista?
content: The Windows bootloader can load Linux, but you have to set it up by hand (you install a Linux bootloader into the partition with Linux on it, then tell the XP bootloader to boot that partition.)  Of course it's much simpler just to install a proper boot loader in the MBR, which can load anything directly (then you can also get it to load memdisk with a 2.88MB floppy image stored as a file on a Linux partition, in case you ever need to boot to DOS or anything and don't want a DOS partition on your hard disk...)

title: Re: oh common.
content:
Actually I think "3D" graphics in a GUI is an excellent idea. Most people have a 3D accelerated video card, which sits idle for the most part unless they're playing games. When windows are drawn on the screen the application has to keep rendering its window content as its windows are moved around and uncovered.

It makes a lot of sense to use that idle 3D processor, and instead of drawing a big flat 2D image over the whole screen, draw each window into a texture, and then layer each texture using the 3D engine to give the appearance of overlapping windows. This would speed up rendering, and make things *very* smooth when moving windows around.

Of course as soon as this idea surfaces someones goes "hey, if the windows are 3D textures we could do cool things like fading windows on and off the screen with hardly any performance hit" and the eyecandy GUI is born [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

And also you can pop up window previews when you mouse over your taskbar, fade background windows when alt+tabbing, and basically anything you can imagine. All with very low CPU usage. Speaking from experience, 3d acceleration in UIs is the best thing to happen since SVGA (on the desktop -- hardware acceleration itself was pretty significant). It doesn't suck up the CPU nearly as much as you might imagine, since the CPU doesn't have to render it.________________

title: Re: Anyone bought/plans to buy Windows Vista?
content:
I got and installed Windows Vista Ultimate. I haven't really had any major problems with it. Here's my pros and cons for it.

Pros:
*Nice looking
*easy to search for stuff and organize stuff
*definitely more secure (I used it to get rid of a nasty virus *on one of my XP hard drives)
*Keeps itself up to date

Cons:
*resouce-hungry: I have a Athlon 64 2.0Ghz CPU, an NVidia 7300 GS 256MB graphics card, and 1.5 Gigs of RAM, and still it uses a fairly good-sized chunk of the stuff. As for those fancy graphics, yeah...they do eat a bit, but you can tone it down by turning off the transparency, turning off Aero in general, or change it to look like classic windows.
*if you're a gamer, it doesn't run certain games, and if it does, they may be a little laggy (then again, this points to resource-hungry, and I could have a better graphics card or more memory...). However, it runs DOSbox perfectly fine. I play Wolfenstein 3D, Scorched Earth, and Bio Menace on it. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-crazy.gif[/img]
*will take a little getting used to, oh, and the occasional "requset for this process to continue" popup is minorly annoying. (I know it's very important though, so I guess it doesn't really bug me as much as it does other people)
*iTunes and Vista do not seem to get along very well...
*as part of the security features, it locks out a bunch of places if you with to transfer or edit stuff in an XP account through Vista...pretty annoying...

So yeah. In the grand scheme of things, I think it's worth it. But there's no pressing need to upgrade if you don't want to. Some people don't want to get it until the first Service pack comes out.

If you use a form of Linux, and you WANT the Aero graphics, there's this handy thing called "[url=http://www.beryl-project.org/]Beryl[/url]". It's kind of like Windowblinds/StyleXP, but it also changes the ways you can search through stuff, and how the windows act. There are many Beryl themes, but there's one that looks like Windows Vista's Aero. I use it for another one of my hard drives which has SuSe Linux installed.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-crazy.gif[/img]
[url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xC5uEe5OzNQ]Comparison vid of Aero and Beryl on YouTube[/url]

So yeah, there's my two cents. On another note, I think I gave more hands-on info about Vista in one post then the lot of you did while bantering about OS comparisons between Windows, Macintosh, and Linux...[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-confused.gif[/img] I thought the original purpose of this topic was questioning about who's gettinging/got Vista and how it works...

Every time I've tried Keen on a VM, the (only horizontal, IIRK) pixel-based scrolling doesn't work and the screen jolts along by one tile every 16 pixels instead.

title: Re: PiXAL
content:
That happens to me even if I run Keen "natively" in Windows XP without DOSBox. It's my monitor's fault, in my case.

I would not recommend anyone to run DOS games in QEMU, they use too much virtual CPU time and cause horrible lags in the emulator.------------------------------
